questions.text: Nivolumab and Relatlimab combination can be used in which of these tumours?
questions.solution:
Nivolumab and Relatlimab combination can be used in patients with Malignant Melanoma.

Both Nivolumab and Relatlimab are Immune checkpoint inhibitors. A combination of Nivolumab, a PD-1 blocking antibody(programmed death receptor-1), and Relatlimab, a LAG-3 blocking antibody (lymphocyte activation gene-3) is indicated for the treatment of patients with unresectable or metastatic melanoma.

Binding of the PD-1 ligands (PD-L1 and PD-L2) to the PD-1 receptor found on T cells, inhibits T-cell proliferation and cytokine production. Upregulation of PD-1 ligands occurs in Malignant melanoma which leads to inhibition of T-cell immune surveillance of tumours. Similarly, the LAG-3 pathway inhibits T-cell proliferation and cytokine secretion. The drugs which inhibit PD-1 or LAG-3 and other similar interactions between the Tumour and Immune cells are termed Immune checkpoint inhibitors.

The synergistic combination of Nivolumab (anti-PD-1) and Relatlimab (anti-LAG-3) results in increased T-cell activation compared to the activity of either antibody alone, as LAG-3 blockade potentiates the anti-tumour activity of PD-1 blockage, inhibiting tumour growth and promoting tumour regression.

The drug combination is given by intravenous route in adults as well as children more than 12 years of age. Adverse effects upon usage include anaemia, lymphocytopenia, increased AST, increased ALT, and Hyponatremia.

Many other immune checkpoint inhibitors have been approved for the treatment of various tumours. Pembrolizumab which acts by inhibiting PD-1, is approved for the treatment of carcinoma endometrium.

Atezolimumab is also an immune checkpoint inhibitor, acts by inhibiting PDL-1, used for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer.

Durvalumab is also a PD-L1 inhibitor and is approved for use in metastatic urothelial cancer.

questions.text: Eflapegrastim belongs to which of the given drug class?
questions.solution:
Eflapegrastim is a Recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF).

FDA has recently approved Eflapegrastim to decrease the incidence of infection, in adult patients receiving myelosuppressive anti-cancer drugs. Anti-cancer drugs can frequently cause Myelosuppression, which manifests as febrile neutropenia and increase the risk of recurrent and severe infection in these patients. Thus, recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) class of drugs are given to correct the neutropenia. Examples of G-CSF are eflapegrastim, pegfilgrastim and filgrastim. 

Eflapegrastim binds to G-CSF receptors on myeloid progenitor cells and neutrophils, triggering signalling pathways that control cell differentiation, proliferation, migration and survival. Adverse effects include fatigue, nausea, diarrhoea, bone pain, headache, pyrexia, anaemia, rash, myalgia, arthralgia, and back pain. 

Other options: Recombinant human erythropoietin like Epoetin alfa and darbepoetin alfa are used in the treatment of anaemias associated with surgery, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions. They increase erythropoiesis.

Recombinant human thrombopoietin like Oprelvekin is used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. It increases thrombopoiesis.

Recombinant human granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor(GM-CSF) like Sargramostim is used for Myeloid reconstitution after bone marrow transplant, Prophylaxis of neutropenia in myelosuppressive chemotherapy and Stem cell mobilization in donor for stem cell transplant.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presents to you following the burn injury as shown in the below image. Your senior consultant advises you to prescribe a topical agent that can remove the eschar. Which of the following agents is best suited for this specific purpose?
questions.solution:
The above image shows burns with eschar and among the above-mentioned topical applications, Anacualase is used to remove eschar.

Eschar is a form of tissue reaction that can form in patients with burns. It is composed of dead tissue and dried secretions from a skin wound following a burn or even an infectious disease of the skin. An eschar prevents topical medications to reach the patient's viable tissue and thus hinders the healing of the burn wounds.

Anacualase is a newly approved topical agent that contains proteolytic enzymes and is indicated for eschar removal in adults with deep partial thickness or full-thickness thermal burn. It acts by dissolving the burn wound eschar through proteolytic enzymes. The most commonly associated adverse reactions are pruritus and pyrexia. Pain during application can be managed by premedications before the burn dressing.

Mafenide acetate either in cream or solution form is an effective topical antimicrobial. It is effective even in the presence of eschar as it can penetrate burn eschar to reach the interface with the patient's viable tissue. But on its own Mafenide acetate does not dissolve and remove the eschar.

Silver sulphadiazine and Silver nitrate are both topical antimicrobial agents used in patients with burns but they cannot penetrate eschar and thus cannot be used in these patients.

questions.text: The image below shows the Sites of action of various antifungal drugs. Which is the site of action for Rezafungin?
questions.solution:
Rezafungin belongs to the Echinocandin group of drugs. It inhibits the activity of the glucan synthase complex marked by site 4 in the image.

Rezafungin is a newly FDA-approved Echinocandin antifungal reserved as a second-line agent for treating candidemia and invasive candidiasis. 1,3-β-D glucan is an essential component of the fungal cell wall which maintains cell integrity. Rezafungin similar to other Echinocandins acts by inhibiting the synthesis of 1,3-β-D-glucan and thereby weakens the fungal cell wall and increases the osmotic susceptibility of candida. It is administered intravenously in patients at least 18 years old. The most common adverse reactions are hypokalemia, pyrexia, diarrhoea, anaemia, vomiting, abdominal pain and constipation.

Site of action of other Antifungal agents:

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Futibatinib, a newly approved drug is used in the treatment of metastasis of which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Futibatinib is a newly FDA-approved drug used to treat locally advanced or metastatic intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma(ICC) is one of the most aggressive tumours which originates from the intrahepatic bile duct. Histologically ICCs are adenocarcinomas. Only a minority of patients present with a resectable disease. Most patients present when the disease has already metastasized to the liver, stomach or colon. 

Futibatinib is a kinase inhibitor indicated for the treatment of adult patients with previously treated, unresectable, locally advanced or metastatic Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma harbouring fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 (FGFR2) gene fusions. The drug is also active in patients with other genetic rearrangements/fusions but the response is best in patients with FGFR gene fusions.

Mechanism of action: Futibatinib inhibits FGFR phosphorylation and downstream signalling and decreases cell viability in cancer cell lines with FGFR alterations. It is metabolised by Cytochrome enzyme-CYP3A. Co-administration of CYP3A inducers and inhibitors should therefore be avoided. The most common adverse reactions are nail toxicity, musculoskeletal pain, constipation, diarrhoea, fatigue, dry mouth, and alopecia.

Currently, Futibatinib is not approved to be used in Gastric Adenocarcinoma, Hepatocellular Carcinoma and Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Tofersen is approved for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Tofersen is approved for the treatment of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Tofersen is an antisense oligonucleotide indicated for treating Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in adults with a mutation in the superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene. It acts by causing degradation of SOD1 mRNA after binding to it, which results in a reduction of SOD1 protein synthesis. The most common adverse effects associated with the use of Tofersen are pain, fatigue, arthralgia, increased WBC count in CSF and myalgia. 

ALS is a progressive motor neuron disease. It presents as upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory functions.

Other options: Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by tremors at rest, rigidity, bradykinesia, gait dysfunction, postural instability, speech difficulty, swallowing impairment, and autonomic disturbances. Levodopa and carbidopa combination is used as the first line of treatment.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. Treatment includes drugs like Donepezil, rivastigmine, Galantamine and Memantine.

Lewy body dementia is a progressive neurodegenerative associated with dementia, psychosis, and features of parkinsonism. The mainstay of treatment is symptomatic management which includes cholinesterase inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs delay the onset of Stage-3 in patients with Stage-2 of Type 1 Diabetes?
questions.solution:
Teplizumab is a recently approved drug used to delay the onset of Stage-3 in patients with Stage-2 of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus(Type 1 DM).

Type 1 DM is caused due to immune-mediated destruction of the pancreatic beta cells and insulin deficiency. Patients usually present in adolescence or early adulthood with classical features of DM. Based on further evaluation, patients with Type 1 DM can be further categorised into three stages.

Stage 1 disease is characterized by the development of two or more islet cell autoantibodies but the maintenance of normoglycemia. Stage 2 disease is defined by continued autoimmunity and the development of dysglycemia(due to progressive Beta cell destruction). Stage 3 is defined by the development of hyperglycemia that exceeds the diagnostic criteria for the diagnosis of diabetes.

Teplizumab is a new drug which can delay the onset of Stage-3 of Type 1 DM in patients with Stage-2 of Type 1 DM. It acts by binding to CD-3 of T cells and possibly does partial agonistic signalling and deactivation of pancreatic beta cell autoreactive T lymphocytes. Thus the progressive destruction of Beta cells in the pancreas is delayed. The adverse effects of the drug include lymphopenia and severe infections, rash, hypersensitivity reactions and headache.

 

Other options: Omaveloxolone is an activator of Nrf2, a newly FDA-approved drug for the treatment of Friedrich’s ataxia.

Insulin is the drug of choice in patients with Type 1 DM, but it does not affect the disease progression.

Erenumab is a CGRPreceptor antagonist used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine

questions.text:
Match the following Seizure types in Column A with the drugs used to treat them in Column B.
Column A Column B
A. West Syndrome 1. Ganaxolone
B. Cyclin-Dependent Kinase-like 5 (CDKL5) deficiency disorder 2. ACTH
C. Lennox Gestaut Syndrome 3. Sodium Valproate
D. Typical Absence Seizure 4. Ethosuximide
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

A. West Syndrome 2. ACTH
B. cyclin-dependent kinase-like 5 (CDKL5) deficiency disorder 1. Ganaxolone
C. Lennox Gestaut Syndrome 3. Sodium Valproate
D. Typical Absence Seizure 4. Ethosuximide

 

West Syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy syndrome that begins in infancy. It is characterized by a triad of Infantile spasms, developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia (on EEG). The drug of choice for West syndrome is ACTH(Adreno Corticotrophic Hormone) injections. The drug of choice for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis is vigabatrin.

Cyclin-dependent kinase-like 5 (CDKL5) deficiency causes developmental encephalopathy which presents with epilepsy, hypotonia, developmental disabilities and cortical visual impairment. Ganaxolone is a recently approved drug for the treatment of seizures associated with CDKL5 deficiency.

The exact mechanism of action of Ganaxolone is unknown, but its anticonvulsant effects are thought to result from positive allosteric modulation of the GABA-A receptor in the CNS. It can be used in adults as well as children older than 2 years of age. The most common adverse reactions associated with the drug are somnolence, pyrexia, salivary hypersecretion and seasonal allergy. 

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome usually starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. It consists of a triad of Developmental delay, Multiple seizure types (including atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures) and characteristic EEG findings (1–2 Hz spike and slow waves). The drug of choice for Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome is Sodium Valproate. Other drugs used for treatment include lamotrigine, topiramate and clobazam. 

Typical absence Seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure occurs in children aged four to ten years and lasts only a few seconds. Ethosuximide and sodium valproate are used as first-line therapy for absence seizures.

 

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

Type of seizure  1st-line antiepileptic drugs

Focal seizures 
  • Carbamazepine
  • Oxcarbazepine 
  • Lamotrigine
  • Levetiracetam
  • Phenytoin
GTCS 
  • Sodium valproate
  • Levetiracetam 
  • Lamotrigine 
Typical absence seizures 
  • Ethosuximide (drug of choice)
  • Sodium valproate
  • Lamotrigine
Atypical absence seizures
  • Sodium valproate 
Myoclonic seizures
  • Sodium valproate (drug of choice)
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate

questions.text: Which of the following is true for Daridorexant?
questions.solution:
Daridorexant is an Orexin Antagonist used for the treatment of Insomnia.

Insomnia is defined as difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep. It may be transient or persistent. Daridorexant is an orexin receptor antagonist indicated for treating adult patients with insomnia characterized by difficulties with sleep onset or sleep maintenance. The orexin neuropeptide signalling system plays a role in wakefulness. Daridorexant blocks the binding of wake-promoting neuropeptides orexin A and orexin B to their receptors suppressing the wake drive. It is an oral preparation and the most common adverse effects are headache and somnolence or fatigue. Suvorexant is also an Orexin Receptor antagonist used for the treatment of insomnia.

Other options: Melatonin analogue approved for the treatment of insomnia is Ramelteon. It is used mainly in conditions with difficulties of sleep onset. Tasimelteon and Agomelatine are other drugs included in this drug class.

Hypocretin neurons activate wake-promoting pathways in the CNS. A deficiency of hypocretin, likely due to autoimmune destruction of hypocretin neurons, produces narcolepsy, a condition of hypersomnia, including excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden attacks of sleep. Melatonin antagonists and Orexin agonists are not used in humans to treat narcolepsy. 

Rather CNS stimulants, which enhance transmission in monoamine pathways like modafinil and armodafinil are used in the treatment of Narcolepsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common adverse effect associated with Bexagliflozin?
questions.solution:
Bexagliflozin is a recently approved drug used for glycemic control in patients with Type 2 DM. The most common adverse effect associated with the drug is Urinary tract infections.

Bexagliflozin is a newly approved drug by the FDA. It is a Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor indicated as an adjunct to diet and exercise to improve glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Inhibiting SGLT2 reduces renal reabsorption of filtered glucose, thereby increasing urinary glucose excretion. This increased glucose load in the urine increases the risk of urinary and genital mycotic infections.

Other adverse effects associated with the use of Bexagliflozin are Ketoacidosis( In patients with Type 1 DM), Lower Limb Amputation, Volume Depletion, Hypoglycemia (with Concomitant Use with Insulin) and Necrotizing Fasciitis of the Perineum (Fournier’s Gangrene).

All the other options are also possible adverse effects that could develop after using Bexagliflozin but occur less frequently than Urinary tract infections. If used in patients with Type 1 DM Bexagliflozin can cause euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) because of the increased excretion of glucose in the urine which induces glucagon secretion which in turn increases the production of glucose and ketones in the liver leading to ketoacidosis.

It also increases the risk of fractures and lower limb amputations due to the creation of an imbalance with the minerals and circulating parathormone and vitamin D.

Concomitant use of Insulin and Bexagliflozin may lead to the development of Hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with a staggering gait and a history of frequent falls. On examination, deep tendon reflexes are depressed and nystagmus is seen. PCR reveals expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat. Which of the following drugs can be used for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Features of frequent falling, staggering gait, depressed deep tendon reflex and nystagmus, and the expansion of GAA trinucleotide repeats in a 19-year-old male suggest Friedrich's ataxia. Omaveloxolone is a newly FDA-approved drug for the treatment of Friedrich’s ataxia.

Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder generally occurring in individuals less than 25 years of age. It is caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of a gene on chromosome 9q13 that encodes frataxin. Patients present with clinical features of dysarthria, progressive staggering gait, frequent falls, nystagmus, and titubation(nodding head and body movements).

Omaveloxolone was recently approved by the FDA for treating Friedrich’s ataxia in adults and adolescents aged 16 years and older. Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), bilirubin, B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP), and lipid profiles should be documented prior to initiating the oral drug.

The exact mechanism of action of the drug is unknown, but it has been shown to activate the Nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)like 2 (Nrf2) pathway in vitro and in vivo in animals and humans. The Nrf2 pathway is involved in the cellular response to oxidative stress. 

Adverse effects on administration are elevation of liver enzymes (AST/ALT), elevation of BNP(Brain Natriuretic Peptide), headache, nausea, abdominal pain, fatigue, diarrhea, and musculoskeletal pain. Omaveloxolone is metabolized by the CYP3A4 cytochrome enzyme and hence can interact with other CYP3A4 substrates like Midazolam. 

Other options: 

Trofinetide(option A)is a synthetic analogue of IGF-1(Insulin-like Growth Factor-1) recently approved for the treatment of Rett Syndrome.

Zavegepant(option C) is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist used to treat acute attacks of migraine.

Erenumab(option D)is a monoclonal antibody against the CGRP receptor used in the prevention of migraine.

questions.text: Daprodustat, a newly approved drug is used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Daprodustat is a newly approved drug by the FDA used for treating Anemia in CKD patients.

In patients with CKD(Chronic Kidney Disease), there is decreased erythropoietin production which in turn leads to the development of Anemia.

Daprodustat is a reversible inhibitor of HIF-PH(Hypoxia-inducible factor–prolyl hydroxylase domain). This activity results in the stabilization and nuclear accumulation of HIF transcription factors, leading to increased transcription of the HIF-responsive genes, including erythropoietin and thereby correcting Anemia. However, an optimal response to treatment with Daprodustat occurs only when iron stores are adequate to complement the increased erythropoietin levels for producing new RBCs.It is reserved for Patients who have been receiving dialysis for at least four months.

Daprodustat is given as once-daily oral preparation. The most common adverse reactions are hypertension, thrombotic vascular events, and abdominal pain. It increases the risk of thrombotic vascular events, including major adverse cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction, stroke and venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: Rozanolixizumab is indicated for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Rozanolixizumab is a newly FDA-approved drug indicated for use in patients with generalised Myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is a Neuromuscular-junction(NMJ) disorder due to autoimmune damage to the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the NMJ. It is characterized by weakness and muscle fatigue. Weakness increases with usage and muscle movement is difficult at the end of the day. It affects proximal muscles leading to weakness of the limbs. Ocular features like ptosis and diplopia can also be seen. Treatment includes Anticholinesterase drugs like Pyridostigmine, immunosuppression and even Thymectomy if the condition is associated with a Thymoma. Recently Rozanolixizumab has been approved for treating cases of generalised Myasthenia gravis.

Rozanolixizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that binds to the Fc receptor (FcRn) of the circulating Autoantibodies against the Acetyl-choline receptors. This neutralisation of auto-antibodies provides clinical relief of symptoms. It is administered through a subcutaneous route. The most common adverse reactions noted with the use of Rozanolixizumab in patients with generalised Myasthenia Gravis are headache, infections, diarrhoea, fever, hypersensitivity reactions and nausea.

Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the presynaptic membrane at the NMJ. Patients present with proximal muscle weakness of the lower limbs, ptosis, and diplopia. However, symptoms might improve after brief exercise. Treatment involves plasmapheresis, immunotherapy, and drugs such as 3,4-diaminopyridine (3,4-DAP) and pyridostigmine.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is X-linked muscular dystrophy due to mutations in the dystrophin gene. It most commonly affects boys in their childhood. Patients initially present with proximal muscle weakness predominantly in the lower limbs. Calf muscle hypertrophy is a cardinal feature. Other features include mental retardation, cardiac failure, and myoglobinuria. Treatment includes corticosteroids, Eteplirsen and Casimersen. 

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder affecting multiple systems. It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy. The treatment is mainly symptomatic however, mexiletine is indicated for reducing myotonia.

questions.text: Pegunigalsidase, a newly approved drug is used in the treatment of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Pegunigalsidase alfa or simply Pegunigalsidase is a newly approved drug by the FDA used for treating adults with Fabry Disease.

Fabry disease is caused due to alpha-galactosidase deficiency leading to the accumulation of globotriaosyl-ceramide. It is an X-linked recessive disorder, hence full symptoms are only seen in males. They usually present as skin rashes and kidney failure. Treatment is with enzyme replacement therapy (recombinant alpha-Gal A or migalastat). Recently The FDA approved Pegunigalsidase for treating confirmed cases of Fabry Disease.

Pegunigalsidase is a modified recombinant human alpha-galactosidase A enzyme. In patients with Fabry disease, it acts as an exogenous source of alpha-galactosidase A. The most common adverse reactions are infusion-associated reactions( and hypersensitivity), nasopharyngitis, headache, diarrhea, fatigue, nausea, back pain, and sinusitis.

Other options: Option A - Tay-Sachs disease is caused due to hexosaminidase A deficiency leading to the accumulation of Glucocerebroside. Clinical symptoms include mental retardation, blindness, and muscular weakness. 

Option C- Gaucher Disease is a genetic disorder due to glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase) deficiency. Patients present with hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, osteoporosis, and avascular necrosis of the femur. Imiglucerase is used as enzyme replacement therapy.

Option D - Niemann-Pick disease is caused due to sphingomyelinase deficiency leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin. Clinical features include mental retardation and hepatosplenomegaly.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

questions.text: Sutimlimab is used in the treatment of which of the given conditions?
questions.solution:
Sutimlimab is used in the treatment of Cold Agglutinin disease.

Cold Agglutinin disease is a type of immune hemolytic anaemia which is caused by IgM antibodies that bind to red cells avidly at low temperatures (0°C to 4°C) but not at 37°C, resulting in vascular obstruction and extravascular hemolysis. Cold agglutinin antibodies sometimes appear transiently following certain infections, such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Epstein-Barr virus and CMV.

Clinically it presents with pallor, cyanosis, and the Raynaud phenomenon of fingers, toes and ears when exposed to cold temperatures of 0° C to 4°C. The disorder is usually self-limiting but Chronic cold agglutinin immune hemolytic anaemia which may occur in certain B-cell neoplasms requires treatment. Sutimlimab is one of the newly approved drugs which can be used to manage chronic and severe Cold Agglutinin disease.

Sutimlimabis is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the classical complement pathway by binding to complement protein C1s (s subcomponent of C1) thus preventing the deposition of complement opsonins on the surface of RBCs. This inhibits hemolysis in patients with Cold Agglutinin disease. The most common adverse reactions associated with Sutimlimab are Respiratory tract infection, diarrhoea, cough, arthralgia and peripheral oedema. 

Warm antibody immune hemolytic anaemia is caused by antibodies that bind to Rbcs at 37 degrees Celsius. It may be idiopathic, or secondarily caused by drugs such as alpha-methyldopa, other autoimmune diseases such as SLE, or lymphoid neoplasms. 

 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA). It is chronic hemolytic anaemia that is characterized by intravascular hemolysis causing hemoglobinuria. Apart from hemolysis, other features like pancytopenia and venous thrombosis are also seen.

Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH) is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies which are produced often in response to a viral infection. This antibody is a biphasic hemolysin. i.e., the antibody binds to RBC at colder temperatures but hemolysis occurs at a core temperature of 37°C leading to intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and usually recover within 1 month.

 

Related Pearl: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia

Autoimmune(e.g., SLE)

Infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae and EBV)

Lymphoproliferative diseases

questions.text:
Given below are a few Biological therapies used in the management of Psoriasis. Match the drugs to their target site of action.
Biological therapy Target Site
A. Deucravacitinib 1. TNF‐α
B. Brodalumab 2. IL-12/23
C. Etanercept 3. TYK-2 
D. Ustekinumab  4. IL-17
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Biological therapy Target Site
A. Deucravacitinib 3. TYK-2 
B. Brodalumab 4. IL-17
C. Etanercept 1. TNF‐α
D. Ustekinumab  2. IL-12/23

Psoriasis is a group of common chronic inflammatory and proliferative conditions of the skin, associated with systemic manifestations in many organ systems. The most characteristic lesions consist of red, scaly, sharply demarcated, indurated plaques, present particularly over the extensor surfaces and scalp.

Biological treatments are part of Systemic therapy for Psoriasis. They are newer and well-established for managing moderate to severe psoriasis.

Deucravacitinib is a Tyrosine kinase 2 (TYK2) inhibitor indicated for the treatment of adults with moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis who are candidates for systemic therapy or phototherapy. It has been recently approved by FDA. The most common adverse reactions associated with Deucravacitinib are upper respiratory infections, blood creatine phosphokinase increased, herpes simplex, mouth ulcers, folliculitis, and acne. 

Ustekinumab is a fully human IgG1  monoclonal antibody against the p40 subunit that is common to both IL‐12 and IL‐23. It is indicated in patients with moderate to severe psoriasis. Dizziness, sore throat and joint pain are the most common side effects associated with Ustekinumab. 

Brodalumab is a fully human IL‐17RA monoclonal antibody used in the management of moderate to severe psoriasis. It leads to black tarry stools, lethargy and joint pain as the most common adverse effects.

Etanercept is a fully human soluble TNF‐α receptor fusion protein that binds and neutralizes TNF‐α, in psoriasis. Hypersensitivity is the most notable and severe adverse effect seen with Etanercept.

questions.text: A man who presented with features of anemia was treated with Mitapivat after lab investigations. Which condition is he likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a man with hemolytic anaemia, treated with Mitapivat suggests the diagnosis of Pyruvate kinase deficiency.

The mature erythrocyte lacks mitochondria and is completely dependent on glycolysis to produce ATP. Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme required for the process of glycolysis. In cases of pyruvate kinase deficiency, the anaemia observed is a consequence of the reduced rate of glycolysis, leading to decreased ATP production. This leads to alterations in the red blood cell membrane causing changes in the cell's shape and later phagocytosis by the cells of the reticuloendothelial system. This premature death and lysis of the red blood cell result in hemolytic anaemia. It occurs more frequently in infants and newborns, but cases can also present in adulthood.

Mitapivat is a recently approved oral drug which is a pyruvate kinase activator indicated for the treatment of hemolytic anaemia in adults with pyruvate kinase (PK) deficiency. It allosterically binds to the pyruvate kinase tetramer and increases pyruvate kinase (PK) activity. The most common adverse reactions are back pain, arthralgia, decreased estrone and estradiol (in males) and increased urate levels.

The severe form of the disease requires regular packed red cell transfusion with iron chelation and folic acid supplementation.

Other options: Option A - Glucose 6 Phosphatase Dehydrogenase(G6PD) is an enzyme of the Hexose monophosphate pathway. G6PD deficiency also causes Hemolytic anaemia but it is not treated with Mitapivat.

Option C- 5' Nucleotidase deficiency also leads to hemolytic anaemia. The hallmark of this enzyme deficiency is the presence of pronounced basophilic stippling and accumulation of pyrimidine nucleotides (RNA remnants) within erythrocytes. Mitapivat is not used for treatment.

Option D - The deficiency of Aspartoacylase leads to Canavan disease. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder, which leads to excessive excretion of N-acetyl aspartic acid in the urine. It is characterized by leukodystrophy and does not cause hemolysis.

questions.text: Omidenepag has been recently approved for the treatment of Glaucoma. Which of the given drugs has a mechanism of action most similar to that of Omidenepag?
questions.solution:
Omidenepag is a Prostaglandin-E receptor agonist. Amongst the given options, its mechanism of action is most similar to Latanoprost, a Prostaglandin-F receptor agonist.

Omidenepag is a relatively selective PG-E2(Prostaglandin E2) receptor agonist which decreases intraocular pressure (IOP) by increasing uveoscleral outflow from the anterior chamber of the eye. In this way, it acts similarly to Latanoprost, a selective PGF2-alpha receptor agonist that reduces IOP by increasing uveoscleral outflow. Both of these drugs are classified as Prostaglandin Receptor agonists(Prostaglandin analogues).

Similar to latanoprost the adverse effects include iris pigmentation, eyelash changes, ocular Inflammation and macular edema. It may also lead to conjunctival hyperemia, photophobia and blurred vision.

Other options: Brimonidine is a selective alpha agonist used in glaucoma. It acts mainly by decreasing the aqueous production and thus lowering the IOP.

Betaxolol is a selective beta 1 blocker that is used in glaucoma and reduces IOP by decreasing the aqueous production.

Dorzolamide is a Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in glaucoma, acting by reducing aqueous production.

 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: Perfluorohexyloctane is used for:

choices.text: As a treatment for dry eye

questions.solution:
Perfluorohexyloctane is used for the treatment of dry eye. 

Dry eye disease occurs due to inadequate tear volume and function, resulting In unstable tear film and ocular surface disease. Many conditions can lead to dry eye including Sjögren syndrome, Vitamin A deficiency, Follicular conjunctivitis, Wearing contact lenses and Trachoma. Tear film tests (Schrimer's test, Tear film break up test and Rose Bengal staining) are used to diagnose Dry eye disease.

Treatment for dry eye includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs).

Recently the FDA approved Perfluorohexyloctane as an ophthalmic solution for treating dry eye. It is used as eyedrops to be instilled four times a day. It forms a monolayer at the tear film's air-liquid interface, which is expected to reduce evaporation. The most common adverse effect associated with the use of Perflurohexyloctane is blurred vision.  Rarely it can lead to conjunctival redness.

 

 

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is approved for prophylaxis against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection?
questions.solution:
Nirsevimab is a monoclonal antibody recently approved by the FDA to be used as a prophylaxis against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection.

RSV is responsible for more than half of the cases of bronchiolitis in infants less than 1 year of age. It generally presents as a fever with cough and wheezing. It has a very high infectivity and transmission is by close contact and droplet transmission. Nasopharyngeal swabs and nasal washings are collected as samples. They are inoculated in cell culture (HeLa or Hep-2) immediately after collection. In cultured cells, RSV shows characteristic giant cells and syncytial formation.

The image given below shows giant cells and syncytial formation seen in RSV infection:

Nirsevimab is a monoclonal antibody with activity against RSV. One dose of Nirsevimab, administered as a single intramuscular injection prior to or during RSV season, may provide protection during the RSV season. Possible adverse effects include rash and injection site reactions.

Other options: Ribavirin is used for treating RSV infections but is not approved for use as a prophylactic agent.

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE indicated in asthma.

Oseltamivir is used for the treatment of avian influenza and is not recommended to be used for RSV.
